post_title: Chat app Telegram challenges Meta with the launch of new 'Business' features and revenue-sharing
title: Telegram Business: Streamlining Communication for Businesses
post_content:
Telegram is making a bold move to challenge Meta's dominance in the messaging app market with the launch of Telegram Business, a set of features aimed at businesses as well as support for ad-revenue sharing. The features, which can be accessed by subscribing to the paid Premium version, are designed to be easy to use and offer a variety of customization options.

Telegram Business offers a range of features that can be used by businesses to improve their communication with customers, including a customized start page, preset replies, greeting and away messages, chatbots, tags for chats, links to chat, and more. These features can be used by businesses to provide better customer service, streamline their communication processes, and improve their overall efficiency.

In addition to the features offered by Telegram Business, the company is also generating revenue through ad-revenue sharing and the sale of Premium subscriptions. Telegram's public channels with at least 1,000 subscribers can now generate 50% of the revenue from ads shown in their channels, which can provide a significant source of income for businesses that use the platform.

The launch of Telegram Business is part of the company's push towards profitability, with founder Pavel Durov announcing that he expects the app to become profitable by 2025. The features offered by Telegram Business are designed to be an attractive offering for businesses looking for an alternative to Meta's apps, which have dominated the messaging app market for years.

Overall, Telegram Business is a promising development for businesses looking for a more efficient and customizable messaging app. With a range of features designed to improve communication with customers, the platform is well-positioned to challenge Meta's dominance in the market.
meta_desc: Telegram's new "Telegram Business" feature set for businesses includes customized start pages, preset replies, chatbots, and more. Ad-revenue sharing and Premium subscriptions are also available. With the push towards profitability, Telegram is becoming an attractive alternative to Meta's messaging app dominance.

post_title: Footage from 2020 shows Astra rocket exploding during prelaunch testing
title: Title: Astra's Rocket 3.0 Explodes during Prelaunch Testing in March 2020
post_content:
Astra's Rocket 3.0 suffered a catastrophic end during prelaunch testing in March 2020, as shown in footage obtained by TechCrunch. The explosion, which occurred at Alaska's Pacific Spaceport Complex, was initially reported as an "anomaly," an industry term for any issue that deviates from the expected outcome.

At the time, Astra CEO Chris Kemp told TechCrunch that the rocket "suffered an anomaly following an otherwise successful day of testing in Kodiak in preparation for a launch this week." However, the company's hardware was the only thing harmed, and they did not attempt a launch after that week. Meanwhile, Alaska Aerospace CEO Mark Lester told local reporters that the company was executing its emergency checklist and requested everyone to stay clear of the area to allow the crew to address the situation.

The video clip shows the micro launcher bursting into flames, indicating that the vehicle did not survive. It would have been Astra's third orbital launch attempt.

At the time, Astra was taking such failures in stride, with the expectation that every launch would not have to be perfect. Astra CEO Chris Kemp summed it up in a May 2022 interview: "The expectation I think that a lot of people have is every launch has to be perfect. I think what Astra has to do, really, is we have to have so many launches nobody thinks about it anymore."

Despite being one of the biggest success stories for space industry investors, with the startup going public in July 2021 at a $2.1 billion valuation after raising nearly $500 million for its ultra-low-cost launch plans, Astra's plans failed to materialize, and after months of burning cash, the company's board quietly accepted a take-private deal from Kemp and CTO Adam London at a stock price of just $0.50 per share. The deal is expected to close sometime this quarter, at which time Astra will cease trading on the Nasdaq.

Astra did not return a request for comment on the 2020 launch failure.

2-word keyphrase: Astra rocket explosion
